awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Cryptographic Data Protection in Modern Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Continuing major breaches and security compromises of computer systems motivate a promising new approach to data protection: encrypt the data so that even if stolen, it will be useless to the attacker, yet reveal just enough information about the data so that commodity systems such as databases and Web servers can still operate on it.  This is called property-revealing encryption (PRE), and has already found its way to academic and commercial products that protect sensitive data in cloud services. This project is a comprehensive investigation of whether, when, and how can property-revealing encryption adequately protect sensitive data. This investigation is informed by close engagement with industry and understanding of the needs and requirements of protecting users' data.

This project comprises three research thrusts, spanning the range from theoretical foundations to security analysis to design and implementation of prototype systems.  The first thrust develops cryptographic definitions and security models for property-revealing encryption (PRE) schemes, as well as developing a hierarchy of threat models and inference methods.  The second thrust focuses on developing a unified methodology for measuring and exploiting information leakage when PRE schemes are deployed on realistic data in actual distributed systems. The final thrust designs and implements secure systems that use cryptographic data protection safely and securely, focusing on a small number of key applications that showcase essential PRE functionality.

por.por_cntn:
Data breaches are an unfortunate fact of life. By exploiting bugs or corrupting company insiders, adversaries regularly obtain and exploit information about millions of people. Breaches happen for a variety of reasons, and no system will ever be perfectly secure. Even systems that encrypt their data will fall prey to hackers who can simply steal the decryption key when they break in.


This project envisions more secure systems that will be much harder to break into. The primary difference from the status quo is that decryption keys will no longer be stored with the encrypted data. Thus when attackers compromise a server, they will not simply find the keys lying around. Instead, those keys will reside with users, on their endpoints, leaving attackers unable to decrypt the information they steal. This architecture is often called "client-side encryption" (CSE).


Realizing a vision of widespread CSE is a multi-decade, many-faceted agenda of the cryptography and security communities. In the past several years, CSE has been widely deployed for messaging apps, and we expect that CSE will one day be popular in file-storage apps, hosted databases, and more.


The specific contributions of this project included new ways to build CSE-enable systems that allowed service providers to work with encrypted data without decrypting.  This project developed a prototype for the best to-date searching functionality on an encrypted file-storage service, and another encrypted search system that distributed trust among multiple devices. One of these constructions has been implemented and deployed by a start-up.


Last Modified: 09/01/2022
Modified by: David Cash
